name: Direct Volume Access
description:
Adversaries may directly access a volume to bypass file access controls and file system monitoring. Windows allows programs to have direct access to logical volumes. Programs with direct access may read and write files directly from the drive by analyzing file system data structures. This technique bypasses Windows file access controls as well as file system monitoring tools. (Citation: Hakobyan 2009)
Utilities, such as NinjaCopy, exist to perform these actions in PowerShell. (Citation: Github PowerSploit Ninjacopy)
data_sources: Command: Command Execution, Drive: Drive Access
detection:
Monitor handle opens on drive volumes that are made by processes to determine when they may directly access logical drives. (Citation: Github PowerSploit Ninjacopy)
Monitor processes and command-line arguments for actions that could be taken to copy files from the logical drive and evade common file system protections. Since this technique may also be used through [PowerShell](T1059.001), additional logging of PowerShell scripts is recommended.

lookup_data.description: Detects access to a raw disk on a host to evade detection by security products.
lookup_data.raw:
author: Janantha Marasinghe
date: 2022/12/20
description: Detects access to a raw disk on a host to evade detection by security
  products.
detection:
  condition: selection_debugfs | near selection_tools
  selection_debugfs:
    a0: debugfs
    type: EXECVE
  selection_tools:
    a0:
    - df
    - lsblk
    - pvs
    - fdisk
    - blkid
    - parted
    - hwinfo
    - inxi
    type: EXECVE
  timeframe: 5m
falsepositives:
- Unknown
id: fb0647d7-371a-4553-8e20-33bbbe122956
level: medium
logsource:
  product: linux
  service: auditd
references:
- https://twitter.com/0xm1rch/status/1600857731073654784?s=20&t=MdrBPqv4hnBEfAJBayMCZA
- https://github.com/Neo23x0/auditd/blob/master/audit.rules
status: experimental
tags:
- attack.defense_evasion
- attack.t1006
title: Use of Debugfs to Access a Raw Disk

lookup_data.description: Detects raw disk access using uncommon tools, which could indicate possible defense evasion attempts
lookup_data.raw:
author: Teymur Kheirkhabarov, oscd.community
date: 2019/10/22
description: Detects raw disk access using uncommon tools, which could indicate possible
  defense evasion attempts
detection:
  condition: not 1 of filter_*
  filter_Keybase:
    Image|endswith: \Keybase\upd.exe
  filter_floppy:
    Device|contains: floppy
  filter_generic:
    Image|startswith:
    - C:\Program Files\
    - C:\Program Files (x86)\
    - C:\Windows\System32\
    - C:\Windows\SystemApps\
    - C:\Windows\WinSxS\
    - C:\Windows\servicing\
    - C:\Windows\CCM\
    - C:\Windows\uus\
  filter_github_desktop:
    Image|contains: \AppData\Local\GitHubDesktop\app-
    Image|endswith: \resources\app\git\mingw64\bin\git.exe
    Image|startswith: C:\Users\
  filter_microsoft_appdata:
    Image|contains|all:
    - C:\Users\
    - \AppData\
    - \Microsoft\
  filter_nextron:
    Image|endswith: \thor.exe
    Image|startswith: C:\Windows\Temp\asgard2-agent\
  filter_setuphost:
    Image: C:\$WINDOWS.~BT\Sources\SetupHost.exe
  filter_specific:
    Image:
    - C:\Windows\UUS\amd64\MoUsoCoreWorker.exe
    - C:\Windows\explorer.exe
  filter_ssd_nvme:
    Image|endswith:
    - \HostMetadata\NVMEHostmetadata.exe
    - \Executables\SSDUpdate.exe
    Image|startswith: C:\Windows\Temp\
  filter_startmenu_xphost:
    Image|endswith: \StartMenuExperienceHost.exe
    Image|startswith: C:\Windows\SystemApps\Microsoft.Windows.StartMenuExperienceHost
  filter_system_images:
    Image:
    - System
    - Registry
  filter_system_process:
    ProcessId: 4
  filter_windefender:
    Image|endswith: \MsMpEng.exe
    Image|startswith: C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender\Platform\
  filter_windows_update_box:
    Image|endswith: \WindowsUpdateBox.exe
    Image|startswith: C:\Windows\SoftwareDistribution\Download
falsepositives:
- Legitimate Administrator using tool for raw access or ongoing forensic investigation
fields:
- ComputerName
- Image
- ProcessID
- Device
id: db809f10-56ce-4420-8c86-d6a7d793c79c
level: low
logsource:
  category: raw_access_thread
  product: windows
modified: 2023/01/18
references:
- https://www.slideshare.net/heirhabarov/hunting-for-credentials-dumping-in-windows-environment
status: test
tags:

title: Potential Defense Evasion Via Raw Disk Access By Uncommon Tools

atomic_tests.name: Read volume boot sector via DOS device path (PowerShell)
atomic_tests.description:
This test uses PowerShell to open a handle on the drive volume via the `\\.\` [DOS device path specifier](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/io/file-path-formats#dos-device-paths) and perform direct access read of the first few bytes of the volume.
On success, a hex dump of the first 11 bytes of the volume is displayed.

For a NTFS volume, it should correspond to the following sequence ([NTFS partition boot sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NTFS#Partition_Boot_Sector_(VBR))):
```
           00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 0A 0B 0C 0D 0E 0F

00000000   EB 52 90 4E 54 46 53 20 20 20 20                 Ã«R?NTFS
```
